summary: peste des petits ruminants virus (PPRV) is a contagious viral disease of domestic and wild small ruminants. the disease was first reported in the Ivory Coast area of west africa in 1942. the virus is a non-segmented, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. type I IFNs bind to IFN-/ receptors to induce autophosphorylation of janus kinase 1 (JAK1) and tyrosine kinase 2 (TYK2). phosphorylated STAT1 and STAT2 form heterodimers that bind to IFN-regulatory factor 9 (IRF9) to form IFN-stimulated gene factor 3 (ISGF3). paramyxoviruses have evolved multiple strategies to counteract IFN-mediated antiviral effect through different viral proteins. the P gene products of paramyxoviruses have been implicated in blocking host IFN response. the P protein blocks STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation through interacting with STAT1 and STAT2. the HEK-293T cells were grown to 50% confluency and then infected with 0.1 MOI of PPRV. the infected cells were treated with IFN P proteins of paramyxoviruses have two main functions in the viral life cycle. they function as a cofactor of viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. they also serve as a guardian for the correct assembly of nucleocapsids. yrosine 110 (Y110) in the P protein is critical for its interaction with STAT1. mutation of Y110 in the P protein completely abrogated its interaction with STAT1. the Y110 in the MV P protein is also required to block STAT1 phosphorylation.
